1065677734615994368.text: Almost all scientists seem to agree Climate Change is occuring.  A majority agree there is significant human input although variations on the relative magnitude thereof.  Beyond that there seems no clear scientific consensus.  A political plurality probably though.

1065676920937885696.text: Special pleading?  Really?  That's not convincing anyone not already in agreement with you.  Clearly many scientists aren't convinced of any 'crisis' to be dealt with.

1065699527527710721.text: You missed the point: THIS particular survey was among professionnals who work for Big oil (in Alberta), it wasn't a survey of the scientific community at large. They were obviously biased by their paycheck to find non-human causes to climate change.

1066022525560283136.text: Obvious attempts to eliminate differences of opinion within academia on this issue, have really 'poisoned the well', possibly irretrievably.  Charges of Lysenkoism   are now routine and routinely believed.  Academia has gotten itself into a real cleft fork here.

1066023442418290688.text: and THAT will be hugely costly over time.  Science & Politics are a very, very destructive mix.

1066021638443941888.text: Regrettably public perception of academia as overwhelmingly doctrinaire leftists has seriously undermined its public credibility in any case.  Such claims are viewed by a very large part of society as ideologically driven.

1066023113119293440.text: which is actually a far bigger issue than Climate Change, which, frankly, is absolutely not amenable to any effective positive action, except mitigation and adaptation.  But the damage to science as a credible institution may be irreparable.

1066020760848752640.text: Yes, but it was cited as only one instance of many such studies, as well as meta-data reports seriously calling into question exactly what most claims of 'consensus' around this issue actually mean.

1066376363635032066.text:

Would you ask a veterinarian to manage your erectile dysfunction?

1065507405977591809.text:
Poor li'l fella. You mad, bro?

I was laughing at your "we" this and "we" that. You haven't done squat but chirp about things you obviously know nothing about. I think it's probably cause you're 12. Do some readin' boy.

1066387922775994368.text: I do.  That was one example from dozens of alternatives many very recent.  The point is where 'science' becomes advocacy it ceases to be science, becomes politics and consensus evaporates.  Pushing that boundary in hopes it supports advocacy...

1066391023352311810.text: That at least is encouraging.  Many aren't, except as facade. So do keep pushing!  But remember: telling others what to do and taking their money can be a dangerous business.    Consider Trump a really mild example of reaction!

1066388549027606528.text: damages science and undermines public trust in it institutionally far more than it advances some putative 'environmental' policy.  Those policies are hugely 'iff-y' ; the damage to Science deep and lasting.
